title: Marijo Dodik
text:
Marijo Dodik (born 18 February 1974 in <a href="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a>) is a Bosnian retired <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="Striker%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a>.
Club career.
Dodik started his career at <a href="%C5%BDeljezni%C4%8Dar%20Sarajevo">Željezničar Sarajevo</a> before leaving war-torn Bosnia and being picked up by the Belgian side <a href="KV%20Mechelen">Mechelen</a> in 1995, where he spent two seasons in the <a href="Belgian%20First%20Division%20A">Jupiler League</a> and scored 20 goals in a total of 84 appearances. He spent the next season in Turkey's <a href="Sakaryaspor">Sakaryaspor</a>, before moving to <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a> and joining <a href="Slaven%20Belupo">Slaven Belupo</a> in 1998.
He spent his most successful years at Slaven, establishing himself as a first-team regular and the club's most prolific <a href="Prva%20HNL">Prva HNL</a> scorer with 75 goals in 228 appearances in a total of eight seasons between 1998 and 2007. During his time at Slaven he also netted 14 goals in 22 appearances in club's European campaigns in the <a href="UEFA%20Intertoto%20Cup">Intertoto Cup</a>, and holds the record for most goals scored by a player in a single <a href="Prva%20HNL">Prva HNL</a> game, scoring an incredible 6 goals against <a href="NK%20Vara%C5%BEdin%20%281931%E2%80%932015%29">Varteks</a> on 21 October 2000 in a 7–1 win.
In 2007, Slaven refused to renew his contract so he moved to <a href="HNK%20Cibalia">Cibalia</a> where he netted 5 goals in 28 appearances, and in 2008 he went on to <a href="Inter%20Zapre%C5%A1i%C4%87">Inter Zaprešić</a>, where he played until 2009 and his retirement from professional football. Dodik continued, however, playing for lower-tier amateur Croatian and Slovenian teams, such as <a href="NK%20Zelina">NK Zelina</a>, <a href="NK%20Sabarija%20Subotica%20Podravska">NK Sabarija Subotica Podravska</a>, <a href="NK%20Rudar%20Trbovlje">NK Rudar Trbovlje</a> and <a href="NK%20Mladost%20Mali%20Otok">NK Mladost Mali Otok</a>.
International career.
He made his debut for <a href="Bosnia%20and%20Herzegovina%20national%20football%20team">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> in a May 1998 <a href="friendly%20match">friendly match</a> away against <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">Argentina</a> and has earned a total of 4 caps, scoring 1 goal. He scored that goal in a <a href="2002%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">2002 World Cup qualifier</a> against <a href="Liechtenstein%20national%20football%20team">Liechtenstein</a> in 2001. His final international was a March 2002 friendly against <a href="North%20Macedonia%20national%20football%20team">Macedonia</a>.
